content: Private First Class Franklin Runyon Sousley, born on September 19, 1925, in Hilltop, Kentucky, served as a marine in the United States Marine Corps from January 5, 1944, to March 21, 1945. He graduated from Fleming County High School in May 1943 and enlisted in the Marine Corps, eventually becoming a private first class. Sousley landed on Iwo Jima on February 19, 1945, and actively participated in the battle for the islands. Private First Class Franklin Runyon Sousley, part of the United States Armed Forces, raised a larger flag on Mount Suribachi on February 23, 1945, immortalizing American bravery during World War II. He was killed in combat by a Japanese sniper on March 21, 1945, and originally buried in the 5th Marine Division Cemetery at Iwo Jima. Private First Class Franklin Runyon Sousley was killed in combat on March 21, 1945, during World War II. His remains were returned to the United States and he was laid to rest at Elizaville Cemetery in Kentucky. He was posthumously awarded the Purple Heart and other medals. Mr. Troy Bowling, a Marine from Easy Company, served during the campaign to end the war against Japan and was among the first to arrive on the beachheads of Iwo Jima. He passed away on June 17, 2017, at the age of 90. During the battle of Iwo Jima, Marine Troy Bowling was critically wounded while securing Mt. Suribachi. He made a commitment to serve mankind if he survived. He was carried to safety and witnessed the iconic moment of the American flag being planted on the mountain. The victory came at a heavy cost with over 6,800 US service members losing their lives. Mr. Bowling, a Marine wounded at Iwo Jima, dedicated over 78,000 volunteer hours at the Lexington VA Medical Center. He held various positions in the Disabled American Veterans organization for 66 years, receiving awards for his service. Additionally, he was inducted into the Kentucky Veterans Hall of Fame for his lifetime dedication to veterans. The Lexington VA Health Care System in Kentucky is designated as such by this Act, while the health care facility at 1101 Veterans Drive will be known as the Troy Bowling Campus.
